data.title: RIZAL Day 2-3.pptx
data.meta_description: RIZAL Day 2-3.pptx - Download as a PDF or view online for free
data.text:
4. VISION A CATHOLIC IGNACIAN MARIAN INSTITUTION OF DIVERSE CULTURE THAT EMPOWERS LEARNERS TOWARD SERVICE FOR THE COMMON GOOD THEREBY CONTRIBUTE TO THE TRANSFORMATION OF THE WORLD

5. MISSION NDRVMCC COMMITS ITSELF TO: 1) DEVELOP IGNACIAN MARIAN LEADERS WHO ARE WITNESSES OF FAITH, EXCELLENCE AND SERVICE. 2)INTENSIFY INSTRUCTIONS BY PURSUING INNOVATIVE PROGRAMS THAT EMPLOY RELEVANT EDUCATIONAL STRATEGIES FOR TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCEMENT AND STEWARDSHIP OF CREATION. 3)ENHANCE LINKAGES AND BUILD UP RESOURCES TO FACILITATE INSTRUCTION, RESEARCH AND COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT FOR QUALITY LIFE.

7. SPAIN AND THE PHILIPPINES IN RIZAL'S TIME •SPANISH RULE WAS IMPOSED IN THE COUNTRY BY CONQUEST. •THE FIRST SPANISH SETTLEMENT WAS ESTABLISHED IN CEBU IN 1565 BYMIGUEL LOPEZ DE LEGASPI. •THE SPANISH CONQUERORS FORCED THE PEOPLE TO ADOPT FOREIGN WAYS AND SPANISH CATHOLICISM THAT THEY NEVER UNDERSTOOD. •THE NATIVE LOST THEIR ANCESTRAL LANDS TO THE CONQUISTADORES BY THE ENCOMIENDA SYSTEM •THERE WERE CHANGES IN THE FORM OF GOVERNMENT AND LAWS THAT TOOK PLACE.

8. SPAIN AND THE PHILIPPINES IN RIZAL'S TIME •SPANIARDS RULE THE PH INDIRECTLY THRU VICEROY OF MEXICO. •SPAIN ASSIGNED AN OFFICER WHO WILL MONITOR THE COLONY •THE CAPITAL OF THE COLONIAL ADMINISTRATION OF SPAIN IS MEXICO.

9. SPAIN AND THE PHILIPPINES IN RIZAL'S TIME •RECOPILACION DE LEYES DE LOS REYNOS DE LAS INDIAS – A LAW RELEASED BY THE CONSEJO IN 1681 WHICH GUIDED THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE COLONIES OF THE SPANISH EMPIRE. •CONSEJO DE INDIAS (LEGISLATIVE BODY) FOR THE COLONIES

10. SPANISH TIME

11. MIGUEL LOPEZ DE LEGASPI •HE WAS BORN IN 1510 IN ZUMARAGGA, SPAIN •HE DIED IN AUGUST 20, 1572 IN MANILA •HE WAS THE FIRST GOBERNADOR IN

12. SPAIN AND THE PHILIPPINES IN RIZAL'S TIME •THE PHILIPPINES BECAME A COLONY OF SPAIN AND SHE BELONG TO THE KING OF SPAIN. •FROM THE BEGINNING OF SPANISH RULE UP TO 1821, THE PHILIPPINES WAS ADMINISTERED BY THE MEXICAN VICEROY IN THE NAME OF THE SPANISH KING. •THE PHILIPPINES DIRECTLY RULED BY MADRID.

13. POLITICAL CONDITION DURING THE 19TH CENTURY: POLITICAL SYSTEM

14. •ROYAL DECREES WERE ISSUED BY THE KING AND OTHER OFFICIALS GOVERNING THE PHILIPPINES THRU THE MINISTRY OF COLONIES ( MINISTRO DE ULTRA MAR) BASED IN MDARID. •THE MOC HELPED THE SPANISH MONARCH MANAGE THE AFFAIRS OF THE COLONIES AND GOVERN THE PHILIPPINES THRU CENTRALIZED GOVERNMENTIN MANILA. •THEY EXERCISE EXECUTIVE, LEGISLATIVE AND RELIGIOUS POWER.

15. GOVERNOR-GENERAL •ALSO CALLED AS GOBERNADOR HENERAL •APPOINTED BY THE SPANISH KING •HE IS THE HEAD OF CENTRAL ADMINISTRATION •THE KING’S REPRESENTATIVE IN THE GOVERNMENTAL MATTERS •HE IS THE VICE-ROYAL PATRON OVER RELIGIOUS MATTERS

16. GOVERNOR-GENERAL •APPOINTED BY THE CONSEJO DE INDIAS •THE HIGHEST SPANISH LEADER IN THE COLONIES •HE HAS THE POWER OF CUMPLACE •CUMPLACE IS THE POWER TO CHOOSE A LAW TO BE IMPLEMENTED IN THE COUNTRY WHERE HE IS ASSIGNED.

17. GOVERNOR-GENERAL •HE ASSIGNED TAXES •HE IS THE HEAD OF THE ROYAL AUDIENCIA •HE HAS THE POWER TO GIVE PARDON FOR THE PRISONERS •HE CAN DECIDE DIFFERENT ISSUES IN THE COUNTRY •HE HAS A SALARY OF 40, 000 PESOS PER ANNUM

18. GOVERNOR-GENERAL •HE EXERCISED EXTENSIVE POWERS AS THE HEAD OF THE STATE AND THE CHURCH •HE ISSUED EXECUTIVE ORDERS AND PROCLAMATIONS •HE WAS THE COMMANDER-IN-CHIEF OF THE MILITARY •HE ALSO EXERCISED LEGISLATIVE POWERS WITH HIS “CUMPLACE”

19. GOVERNOR-GENERAL •HE ENJOYED JUDICIAL POWERS AS AN EX-OFFICIO PRESIDENT OF THE ROYAL AUDIENCIA. •HIS RELIGIOUS DUTY GAVE HIM THE PREROGATIVE TO NOMINATE PRIESTS TO ECCLESIASTICAL POSITIONS AND CONTROL THE FINANCES OF THE MISSION.

20. ACTIVITY 1. GIVE ATLEAST 5 RESPONSIBILITIES OR QUALITIES OF THE GOVERNOR GENERAL. 2POINTS EACH

21. POLITICAL SYSTEM 1) CENTRAL ADMINISTRATION – LEAD BY GOVERNOR GENERAL 2)PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT (ALCADIAS) – LEAD BY CIVIL GOVERNORS 3)CITY GOVERNMENT (CABILDO OR AYUNTAMIENTO) – LEAD BY A MAYOR AND A VICE MAYOR – ALSO CALLED THE CHIEF EXECUTIVES AND CHIEF JUDICIAL MAGISTRATE ALL OF THE ABOVE POSITIONS ARE OCCUPIED BY THE SPANIARDS

22. CENTRAL ADMINISTRATION A.ADVISORY BODIES BOARD OF AUTHORITIES COUNCIL OF ADMINISTRATION SECRETARIAT OF THE CENTRAL GOVERNMENT

23. LOCAL GOVERNMENT a)COMPOSED OF PUEBLO HEADED BY THE GOBERNADORCILLO (LATER CALLED AS CAPITAN) CAN BE ELECTED AT THE BEGINNING OF EVERY YEAR BY THE “PRINCIPALIA” - MADE UP OF INCUMBENT EX-CABEZA DE BARANGAY

24. BARANGAY HEADED BY CABEZA DE BARANGAY - ALSO KNOWN AS TENIENTE DEL BARRIO, THE LEADER OF THE BARANGAY OR BARRIO  THE SMALLEST UNIT OF GOVERNMENT CONSIDERED AS THE HIGHEST POSITION IN THE GOVERNMENT TO WHICH THE NATIVE FILIPINO COULD BE APPOINTED.

25. CABEZA DE BARANGAY •ALSO KNOWN AS TENIENTE DEL BARRIO •MAIN RESPONSIBILITY WAS TO COLLECT TAXES AND TRIBUTES FROM THE FAMILIES •HE RECEIVED 2% OF THE TAX PROCEEDS •HE ALSO RECEIVED 4% OF THE SANCTORUM

26. •THE TERM OF CABEZA DE BARANGAY IS 3 YEARS •SANCTORUM – IS THE TAX PAID TO THE CHURCH EACH YEAR TO COVER THE •3 FIESTAS, NAMELY, ALL SAINTS DAY, HOLY THURSDAY, CORPUS CRISTI

27. IN SHORT •THE ARCHIPELAGO IS DIVIDED INTO DIFFERENT PROVINCES UNDER THE LEADERSHIP OF •ALCALDE MAYOR – HIS POWER IS THE SAME WITH GOBERNADORCILLO BUT LIMITED ONLY TO THE PROVINCE WITH A SALARY OF 1, 500 PER ANNUM •THE PROVINCES ARE DIVIDED INTO PUEBLOS OR TOWN UNDER THE LEADERSHIP OF GOBERNADORCILLO •HIS POWER IS THE SAME WITH THE ALCALDE MAYOR BUT LIMITED ONLY TOTHE PUEBLOS. •HE ALSO HAVE THE POWER OF INDULTO DE COMERCIO

28. •THE PUEBLO OR TOWN IS DIVIDED INTO DIFFERENT BARANGAY OR BARRIO HEADED BY THE CABEZA DE BARANGAY •THE CABEZA HAS THE RESPONSIBILITY TO COLLECT TAXES •HE IS EXEMPTED IN POLO Y SERVICIO

29. THE INDIOS •THEY ARE THE NATIVES •THEY HAVE NO RIGHT TO OCCUPY HIGHER POSITION IN THE GOVERNMENT •ONLY ALLOWED TO RUN FOR GOBERNADORCILLO AND CABEZA DE BARANGAY •SUFFRAGE IS GIVEN TO MALES 23 YEAR OLD AND ABOVE, WELL EDUCATED , HAVE PROPERTIES AND TAX AMOUNTING TO 500 PESOS

30. RESIDENCIA •AN OFFICIAL WHO CHECK THE ABUSE OF POWER OF THE ROYAL OFFICIALS WHO LIVE IN THE COUNTRY

31. VISITADOR •AN OFFICIAL WHO WILL JUST VISIT THE COUNTRY TO CHECK THE ROYAL OFFICIALS.

32. ACTIVITY 2. IDENTIFICATION •NUMBER YOUR PAPERS FROM 1 TO 15. •LISTEN CAREFULLY TO THE NUMBER AND QUESTION TO BE READ TO YOU BY THE INSTRUCTOR. ANSWER WHAT IS BEING ASKED. 1-15

33. OPENING PRAYER

35. VISION A CATHOLIC IGNACIAN MARIAN INSTITUTION OF DIVERSE CULTURE THAT EMPOWERS LEARNERS TOWARD SERVICE FOR THE COMMON GOOD THEREBY CONTRIBUTE TO THE TRANSFORMATION OF THE WORLD

36. MISSION NDRVMCC COMMITS ITSELF TO: 1) DEVELOP IGNACIAN MARIAN LEADERS WHO ARE WITNESSES OF FAITH, EXCELLENCE AND SERVICE. 2)INTENSIFY INSTRUCTIONS BY PURSUING INNOVATIVE PROGRAMS THAT EMPLOY RELEVANT EDUCATIONAL STRATEGIES FOR TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCEMENT AND STEWARDSHIP OF CREATION. 3)ENHANCE LINKAGES AND BUILD UP RESOURCES TO FACILITATE INSTRUCTION, RESEARCH AND COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT FOR QUALITY LIFE.

39. MIGUEL LOPEZ DELEGASPI •NATIVE OF ZUMARRAGA, GUIPÚZCOA •GOES TO MEXICO IN 1545, WHERE HE BECOMES CLERK OF THE CABILDO •APPOINTED IN 1561 TO LEAD EXPEDITION TO DISCOVER WESTERN ISLANDS; •LANDS AT CEBU APRIL 27, 1565: •BEGINS FORT AND TAKES POSSESSION OF CEBU AND NEIGHBORING ISLANDS FOR SPAIN, MAY 8, 1565;

40. MIGUEL LOPEZ DELEGASPI •TAKES POSSESSION OF MANILA, MAY 19, 1571; •ERECTS CITY OF MANILA, JUNE 3, 1571, AND APPOINTS REGIDORS, ETC., JUNE 24, 1571; •DEATH, AUGUST 20, 1572; TERM AS GOVERNOR FEBRUARY 13 (DATE OF FIRST ANCHORAGE NEAR CEBU)-AUGUST 20, 1572; ALSO ADELANTADO OR GOVERNOR OF THE LADRONES.

41. GUIDO DE LABEZARES •APPOINTED ROYAL TREASURER OF LEGAZPI'S EXPEDITION, 1564; •APPOINTED BY MEXICO AUDIENCIA BY SEALED INSTRUCTIONS TO SUCCEED LEGAZPI IN CASE OF THE LATTER'S DEATH; SUCCEEDS TO GOVERNORSHIP, AUGUST 20, 1572; •ORDERS SALCEDO TO SUBDUE ILOCOS AND FOUND TOWN OF FERNANDINA (NOW BIGAN), AND ORDERS SUBJECTION OF CAMARINES, 1573;

42. GUIDO DE LABEZARES •DEFENDS MANILA AGAINST PIRATE LIMAHON, 1574; •APPORTIONS ENCOMIENDA; TERM AS GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM), AUGUST 20, 1572-AUGUST 25, 1575;

43. DR. FRANCISCO DE SANDE •NATIVE OF CÁCERES; SERVES AS ATTORNEY, CRIMINAL JUDGE, AND AUDITOR IN MEXICO; • SUCCEEDS LABEZARES, AUGUST 25, 1575; •FOUNDS CITY OF NUEVA CÁCERES; ARRIVAL OF FIRST FRANCISCANS, 1577; •EXPEDITION TO BORNEO, 1578; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, AUGUST 25, 1575-APRIL, 1580; BECOMES AUDITOR IN MEXICO AUDIENCIA.

44. GONZALO RONQUILLO DE PEÑALOSA •ARRIVES AT MANILA, APRIL, 1580; •ARRIVAL OF BISHOP AND FIRST JESUITS, 1581 ; •IMPOSES IMPORT AND EXPORT DUTIES, 1582 ;

45. GONZALO RONQUILLO DE PEÑALOSA •CONFLICT BETWEEN THE BISHOP AND AUGUSTINIANS, 1582; •SENDS GABRIEL RIVERA TO SPAIN; •DEATH, MARCH 10, 1583; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, APRIL, 1580-MARCH 10, 1583.

46. DIEGO RONQUILLO •NEPHEW OF GONZALO; •APPOINTED GOVERNOR AD INTERIM BY ROYAL DECREE, SUCCEEDING TO GOVERNMENT, MARCH 10, 1583; •FIRST GREAT MANILA FIRE, MARCH 19 , 1583; •TERM AS GOVERNOR MARCH 10, 1583-MAY, 1584.

47. DR. SANTIAGO DE VERA •ARRIVES AT MANILA, MAY 16, 1584; •ESTABLISHES FIRST AUDIENCIA OF MANILA, 1584; •SENDS DIEGO RONQUILLO PRISONER TO SPAIN, 1585; •SENDS EXPEDITION TO MALUCO, 1585;

48. DR. SANTIAGO DE VERA •ARRIVAL OF DOMINICANS FOR THEIR FIRST MISSION, 1587; •CONSTRUCTS FIRST STONE FORT, 1587; •CANDISH CAPTURES "SANTA ANA," NOVEMBER, 4, 1587; •INSURRECTION IN THE BISAYAS, 1588; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, MAY 16, 1584-MAY, 1590; •APPOINTED AUDITOR IN MEXICO AUDIENCIA.

49. GOMEZ PEREZ DASMARIÑAS •APPOINTED GOVERNOR OF PHILIPPINES, 1589; •SAILS FOR MEXICO, DECEMBER 8, 1589; •SAILS FROM ACAPULCO, MARCH 1, 1590; ARRIVES AT MANILA, MAY (JUNE 1, ACCORDING TO HIS OWN LETTER, Q.V., VOL. VIII, P. 268), 1590; •SUPPRESSES AUDIENCIA, 1590;

50. GOMEZ PEREZ DASMARIÑAS •ESTABLISHES REGULAR CAMP, AND FORTIFIES THE WALLS MANILA; •QUARRELS WITH BISHOP; •CONTRACTS WITH ESTEVAN RODRIGUEZ DE FIGUEROA TO CONQUER MINDANAO, MAY 12, 1591; •MURDERED BY CHINESE ROWERS, OCTOBER 25, 1593; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, MAY (OR JUNE 1), 1590-OCTOBER 25, 1593.

51. LICENTIATE PEDRO DE ROJAS •AUDITOR OF MANILA AUDIENCIA, 1584; •LIEUTENANT-ASSESSOR, 1590; •GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM), OCTOBER-DECEMBER (FORTY DAYS) 1593; •WAR AFFAIRS OF ISLANDS IN CHARGE OF DIEGO RONQUILLO; •APPOINTED ALCALDE OF MEXICO, 1593.

52. LUIS PEREZ DASMARIÑAS •SON OF GOMEZ PEREZ DASMARIÑAS •RECEIVES GOVERNORSHIP AD INTERIM, BY VIRTUE OF APPOINTMENT OF FATHER, DECEMBER (ZÚÑIGA SAYS 3), 1593; •FOUNDATION IN MANILA OF CONFRATERNITY OF LA MISERICORDIA, 1594; •ARRIVAL IN MANILA OF CHINESE MANDARINS, 1594;

53. LUIS PEREZ DASMARIÑAS •EMBASSY FROM SIAM, 1595; FIGUEROA'S EXPEDITION TO MINDANAO, 1595; •MORGA ARRIVES AT MANILA AS LIEUTENANT- GOVERNOR, JUNE 11, 1595; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, DECEMBER 3, 1593-JULY 14, 1596 •DR. ANTONIO DE MORGA ACTED AS GOVERNOR AD INTERIM FROM HIS ENTRANCE INTO MANILA, JUNE 11, 1595,

54. FRANCISCO DE TELLO DE GUZMAN •NATIVE OF SEVILLA •APPOINTED GOVERNOR AND PRESIDENT OF AUDIENCIA, WHICH HE IS ORDERED TO REESTABLISH, BY ROYAL DECREE, NOVEMBER 26, 1595; •ENTERS MANILA, JULY 14, 1596; •MARTYRDOM OF FRANCISCANS IN JAPAN, FEBRUARY 5, 1597;

55. FRANCISCO DE TELLO DE GUZMAN •ARRIVAL OF FIRST ARCHBISHOP, MAY 1598; •AUDIENCIA REESTABLISHED, MAY 8, 1598; •ARRIVALS OF FIRST SUFFRAGAN BISHOPS, 1598-1600; •MORO INVASIONS, 1599-1600;

56. FRANCISCO DE TELLO DE GUZMAN •JESUIT SEMINARY OF SAN JOSÉ FOUNDED, 1601; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JULY 14, 1596- MAY, 1602; •DEATH IN MANILA, APRIL 1603.

57. PEDRO BRAVO DE ACUÑA •APPOINTED GOVERNOR OF THE PHILIPPINES AS EARLY AS JANUARY 16, 1600 (SEE VOL. XI, P. 312); •INSTRUCTIONS ISSUED FOR, FEBRUARY 16, 1602; •ARRIVES AT MANILA, MAY, 1602; •SECOND FIRE IN MANILA, APRIL 30, 1603;

58. PEDRO BRAVO DE ACUÑA •FIRST CHINESE INSURRECTION, 1603 ; •EXPEDITION TO MALUCO, JANUARY 15-MAY 31, 1606; •AUDIENCIA RULES DURING HIS ABSENCE; •FIRST JAPANESE INSURRECTION, 1606; •DEATH, JUNE 24, 1606.

59. RODRIGO DE VIVERO •APPOINTED GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM) BY ROYAL DECREE, JULY 7, 1607; •ARRIVES AT MANILA, JUNE 15, 1608; •ISSUES INSTRUCTIONS TO ALCALDES-MAYOR; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JUNE 15, 1608-APRIL (EASTER), 1609; •APPOINTED COUNT OF VALLE, AND GOVERNOR AND CAPTAIN-GENERAL, AND PRESIDENT OF AUDIENCIA OF PANAMA.

60. JUAN DE SILVA •ARRIVES IN MANILA APRIL (EASTER), 1609; BRINGS REINFORCEMENTS OF FIVE COMPANIES; •ARRIVAL OF FOURTH ARCHBISHOP, DIEGO VAZQUEZ DE MERCADO, JUNE 4, 1610; •DEATH, APRIL 19, 1616; AUDIENCIA GOVERNS DURING ABSENCE; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, APRIL, 1609-APRIL 19, 1616.

61. ALFONSO FAJARDO Y TENZA • ARRIVES AT CAVITE, JULY 2, 1618, AND TAKES CHARGE OF GOVERNMENT ON THE DAY FOLLOWING; • FOUNDATION OF CONVENT OF SANTA CLARA, AUGUST-NOVEMBER 1, 1621; • KILLS WIFE FOR ADULTERY, 1621; • CHECKS INSURRECTION IN THE VISAYAS, 1623; • DEATH FROM MELANCHOLY, JULY 11 (DELGADO) OR BEFORE JULY, 23, 1624; • TERM AS GOVERNOR, JULY 3, 1618-JULY, 1624.

62. FERNANDO DE SILVA •NATIVE OF CIUDAD-RODRIGO, •KNIGHT OF THE ORDER OF SANTIAGO, AND FORMER AMBASSADOR TO PERSIA; •APPOINTED GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM) BY VICEROY OF MEXICO; •ARRIVES AT MANILA, JUNE, 1625; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JUNE 1625-JUNE 29, 1626.

63. JUAN NIÑO DE TABORA •ARRIVES AT MANILA, JUNE 29 (RETANA, ESTADISMO, SAYS WRONGLY JULY 29), 1626; • DISPATCHES EXPEDITION AGAINST MOROS, 1627-1630; •BUILDS MANILA BRIDGE AND STRENGTHENS FORTIFICATIONS; •DEATH, JULY 22, 1632; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JUNE 29, 1626-JULY 22, 1632.

64. JUAN CEREZO DE SALAMANCA •APPOINTED GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM) BY VICEROY OF MEXICO; •EXPEDITIONS AGAINST MOROS, 1634-1635; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, ABOUT MIDDLE OF 1633-JUNE 25, 1635.

65. SEBASTIÁN HURTADO DE CORCUERA •GIVES FIRST ORDINANCES FOR GOOD GOVERNMENT IN THE PHILIPPINES, 1642; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JUNE 25, 1635-AUGUST 11, 1644; •ARRESTED AND HELD PRISONER FOR FIVE YEARS BY SUCCESSOR; RELEASED BY ORDER OF KING AND APPOINTED (1659) GOVERNOR OF CANARIES; DEATH AT TENERIFE, AUGUST 12, 1660.

66. SEBASTIÁN HURTADO DE CORCUERA •GIVES FIRST ORDINANCES FOR GOOD GOVERNMENT IN THE PHILIPPINES, 1642; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JUNE 25, 1635-AUGUST 11, 1644; •ARRESTED AND HELD PRISONER FOR FIVE YEARS BY SUCCESSOR; RELEASED BY ORDER OF KING AND APPOINTED (1659) GOVERNOR OF CANARIES; DEATH AT TENERIFE, AUGUST 12, 1660.

67. SABINIANO MANRIQUE DE LARA •ARRIVES AT CAVITE, JULY 22, 1653; •TAKES POSSESSION OF GOVERNMENT, JULY 25 (RETANA, ESTADISMO, SAYS JULY 28), 1653; •EARTHQUAKE IN MANILA, AUGUST 20, 1658; •INSURRECTIONS AMONG NATIVES 1660-1661;

68. SABINIANO MANRIQUE DE LARA •CHINESE INSURRECTION, 1662; •TERM MARKED BY PARTIAL CESSATION IN ECCLESIASTICAL TROUBLES AND OUTBREAKS OF MOROS; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JULY 25, 1653-SEPTEMBER 8, 1663; •RETURNS TO MÁLAGA AFTER RESIDENCIA AND BECOMES PRIEST.

69. DIEGO DE SALCEDO • APPOINTED GOVERNOR BY ROYAL PROVISION, DECEMBER 2, 1661; • ARRIVES AT MANILA, OVERLAND FROM CAGAYAN, SEPTEMBER 8, 1663; • TROUBLES WITH ARCHBISHOP AND ECCLESIASTICS LEAD TO HIS ARREST BY THE HOLY OFFICE OF THE INQUISITION, SEPTEMBER 28, 1668; • TERM AS GOVERNOR, SEPTEMBER 8, 1663-SEPTEMBER 28, 1668; • SENT TO MEXICO FOR TRIAL IN 1669, BUT DIES AT SEA; INQUISITION OF MEXICO EXONERATES(ACQUITTED).

70. JUAN MANUEL DE LA PEÑA BONIFAZ •JUNIOR AUDITOR OF MANILA AUDIENCIA; •SUCCEEDS AS GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM) BY TRICKERY, SEPTEMBER 28 (?), 1668; •TERM AS GOVERNOR SEPTEMBER 28, 1668- SEPTEMBER 24, 1669; •TAKES REFUGE IN RECOLLECT CONVENT.

71. MANUEL DE LEON •ARRIVES IN MANILA, SEPTEMBER 24, 1669; •CONFLICT WITH ARCHBISHOP, 1673; •DEATH, APRIL 11, 1677; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, SEPTEMBER 24, 1669-APRIL 11 , 1677.

72. JUAN DE VARGAS HURTADO •ARRIVES AT MANILA, SEPTEMBER 21 1678; •REBUILDS COLLEGE OF SANTA POTENCIANA; •TROUBLE WITH ARCHBISHOP FELIPE PARDO; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, SEPTEMBER 28, 1678-AUGUST 24, 1684; •HE WAS EXCOMMUNICATED; •RESIDENCIA LASTS FOUR YEARS; •DIES AT SEA ON WAY TO MEXICO, 1690.

73. GABRIEL DE CURUZEALEGUI Y ARRIOLA •ARRIVES AT MANILA, AUGUST 24, 1684; •REINSTATES ARCHBISHOP, AND EXILES AUDITORS; • DEATH, APRIL 17 (DELGADO AND SAN ANTONIO) OR 27 (ZÚÑIGA), 1689; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, AUGUST 24, 1684-APRIL 17 OR 27, 1689.

74. FAUSTO CRUZAT Y GONGORA •ARRIVES AT MANILA, JULY 19 OR 25, 1690; •ISSUES ORDINANCES OF GOOD GOVERNMENT, OCTOBER 1, 1696; •REBUILDS GOVERNOR'S PALACE; •TERM CHARACTERIZED BY ECCLESIASTICAL TROUBLES; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JULY 19 OR 25, 1690-DECEMBER 8, 1701.

75. DOMINGO ZABÁLBURU DE ECHEVARRI •APPOINTED GOVERNOR, SEPTEMBER 18, 1694; •ARRIVES AT MANILA, DECEMBER 8 (SAN ANTONIO SAYS SEPTEMBER), 1701; •ATTENDS TO PUBLIC WORKS; RECEIVES PAPAL LEGATE TO CHINA, CÁRLOS TOMÁS MAILLARD TOURNON, WITHOUT CREDENTIALS (WHICH LEADS TO HIS DISMISSAL BY THE KING), SEPTEMBER, 1704; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, DECEMBER 8, 1701-AUGUST 25, 1709; RETURNS TO SPAIN, 1710.

76. MARTIN DE URZUA Y ARISMENDI •APPOINTED BY ROYAL PROVISION, AUGUST 19, 1704; •ARRIVES AT MANILA, AUGUST 25, 1709; •DIMINISHES NUMBER OF CHINESE AT MANILA; •SCHISM BETWEEN RECOLLECTS, AND OTHER ECCLESIASTICAL TROUBLES; •DEATH, FEBRUARY 4, 1715; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, AUGUST 25, 1709-FEBRUARY 4, 1715.

77. FERNANDO MANUEL DE BUSTILLO BUSTAMENTE Y RUEDA •APPOINTED GOVERNOR BY ROYAL PROVISION, SEPTEMBER 6, 1708; •ARRIVES AT MANILA, AUGUST 9, 1717; •SEVERE IN JUDGMENTS; REËSTABLISHES GARRISON AT ZAMBOANGA; •HIS TROUBLES WITH THE ECCLESIASTICS LEAD TO ARREST OF ARCHBISHOP, AND TO HIS ASSASSINATION BY A MOB OCTOBER 11, 1719; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, AUGUST 9, 1717-OCTOBER 11, 1719.

78. FRAY FRANCISCO DE LA CUESTA •ELECTED ARCHBISHOP OF MANILA, AUGUST 12, 1712; •ARRESTED BY BUSTILLO BUSTAMENTE; •BECOMES GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM), ON REFUSAL OF AUDITORS TO SERVE, OCTOBER 11, 1719; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, OCTOBER 11, 1719-AUGUST 6, 1721 ; •TRANSFERRED TO BISHOPRIC OF MECHOCAN, MEXICO, ENTERING, APRIL 18, 1724; •DEATH, MAY 30 (RETANA) OR 31 (BUZETA AND BRAVO), 1724.

79. TORIBIO JOSÉ COSÍO Y CAMPO • APPOINTED GOVERNOR BY ROYAL PROVISION, JUNE 30, 1720; • ORDERED BY ROYAL INSTRUCTIONS TO INVESTIGATE DEATH OF BUSTAMENTE, OCTOBER 6, 1720; • ARRIVES AT MANILA, AUGUST 6, 1721; • DOES NOT INVESTIGATE BUSTAMENTE'S DEATH, ALTHOUGH ORDERED AGAIN (1724) TO DO SO BY THE KING, ACTING ON THE ADVICE OF THE FRANCISCAN TOTANES AND THE JESUITS; • TROUBLES WITH MOROS CONTINUE THROUGHOUT HIS RULE; • TERM AS GOVERNOR, AUGUST 6, 1721-AUGUST 14, 1729.

80. FERNANDO VALDÉS Y TAMON •APPOINTED BY ROYAL PROVISION, OCTOBER 25, 1727; •ARRIVES AT MANILA, AUGUST 14, 1729; •REFORMS ARMY AND ENGAGES IN OTHER PUBLIC WORKS; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, AUGUST 14, 1729-JULY, 1739; •RETURNS TO SPAIN AND APPOINTED MARISCAL-DE- CAMPO.

81. GASPAR DE LA TORRE •ARRIVES AT MANILA, JULY, 1739; •EXPEDITION OF ADMIRAL GEORGE ANSON OCCURS DURING HIS RULE; HARSH IN GOVERNMENT; •DEATH, SEPTEMBER 21 (BUZETA AND BRAVO SAY 29), 1745; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JULY 1739-SEPTEMBER 21, 1745.

82. FRAY JUAN ARRECHEDERRA •BECOMES GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM), SEPTEMBER 21, 1745; •QUELLS INSURRECTION IN BATANGAS; •FORTIFIES MANILA AND CAVITE AGAINST ENGLISH; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, SEPTEMBER 21, 1745-JULY 20 (BUZETA AND BRAVO, AND MAS SAY JUNE), 1750; •DEATH, NOVEMBER 12, 1751

83. JOSÉ FRANCISCO DE OBANDO Y SOLÍS •ARRIVES AT MANILA, JULY 20, 1750; •TROUBLES WITH AUDIENCIA AND ARCHBISHOP; •TROUBLES WITH MOROS; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JULY 20, 1750-JULY, 1754; •DEATH AT SEA, WHILE ON HIS WAY FROM MANILA TO ACAPULCO, 1755.

84. PEDRO MANUEL DE ARANDÍA SANTISTEBAN •ARRIVES AT MANILA, JULY (RETANA, ESTADISMO, SAYS JUNE), 1754; •REFORMS ARMY AND THEREBY INCURS ENMITIES; •TROUBLES WITH MOROS CONTINUE; •EXPELS INFIDEL CHINESE AND BUILDS ALCAICERÍA OF SAN FERNANDO; •TROUBLES WITH AUDIENCIA AND ARCHBISHOP; •DEATH, MAY 31, 1759; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JULY, 1754-MAY 31, 1759.

85. MIGUEL LINO DE EZPELETA •NATIVE OF MANILA, AND BISHOP OF CEBÚ; •BECOMES GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM), AGAINST CONSENT OF PART OF AUDIENCIA, JUNE (MAS SAYS JULY), 1759; •ARCHBISHOP CLAIMS GOVERNORSHIP ON HIS ARRIVAL AT MANILA, BUT OPPOSED SUCCESSFULLY BY EZPELETA; REVOKES ORDINANCES OF GOOD GOVERNMENT MADE BY ARANDÍA;

86. MIGUEL LINO DE EZPELETA •ROYAL DECREE GIVES GOVERNORSHIP TO ARCHBISHOP, JULY, 1761; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JUNE, 1759-JULY, 1761.

87. MANUEL ROJO •ARCHBISHOP OF MANILA; •TAKES POSSESSION OF CHURCH, JULY 22, 1759; •BECOMES GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM), JULY 1761; •BOMBARDMENT, AND TAKING OF MANILA BY ENGLISH, AND COWARDICE AND IMPRISONMENT OF ARCHBISHOP, OCTOBER, 1762; • TERM AS GOVERNOR JULY, 1761-OCTOBER, 1762, ALTHOUGH MAINTAINED AS GOVERNOR BY ENGLISH UNTIL DEATH; •DEATH AS PRISONER, JANUARY 30, 1764.

88. SIMON DE ANDA Y SALAZAR •APPOINTED BY AUDIENCIA LIEUTENANT OF THE GOVERNOR AND CAPTAIN-GENERAL; •LEAVES MANILA, OCTOBER 4, 1762; •ESTABLISHES CAPITAL IN BACOLOR, PAMPANGA, AND HAS HIMSELF PROCLAIMED GOVERNOR;

89. SIMON DE ANDA Y SALAZAR • BRITISH MAINTAIN ARCHBISHOPAS GOVERNOR UNTIL HIS DEATH, WHO CEDES ISLANDS TO THEM; INSURRECTIONS OF NATIVES AND CHINESE, 1762-1764; •NEGOTIATIONS WITH ENGLISH, 1763-1764; •TERM AS GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM), OCTOBER, 1762- MARCH 17, 1764; •RECEIVES KEYS TO CITY FROM BRITISH, APRIL, 1764.

90. FRANCISCO JAVIER DE LA TORRE •MILITARY OFFICER; BECOMES GOVERNOR (AD INTERIM), MARCH 17, 1764; •BRITISH EVACUATE MANILA, APRIL, 1764; •TRIES TO RESTORE ORDER; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, MARCH 17, 1764- JULY 6, 1765.

91. JOSÉ RAÓN •ARRIVES IN MANILA, JULY 6, 1765; •LE GENTIL ARRIVES AT MANILA, OCTOBER, 1766; •ARCHBISHOP SANTA JUSTA Y RUFINA TAKES HIS SEAT JULY 12, 1767; •HIS CONFLICTS WITH REGULAR CLERGY;

92. JOSÉ RAÓN •RAÓN REVISES ORDINANCES OF ARANDÍA; •EXPULSION OF CHINESE, 1769; •EXPULSION OF JESUITS AND RAÓN'S COLLUSION WITH THEM; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JULY 6, 1,765-JULY, 1770; •DEATH, DURING RESIDENCIAAT MANILA.

93. SIMON DE ANDA Y SALAZAR •DIRECTS LETTER TO KING COMPLAINING OF CERTAIN DISORDERS IN THE PHILIPPINES, ENUMERATING AMONG THEM A NUMBER AGAINST THE FRIARS, APRIL 12, 1768; •ARRIVES AT MANILA AS GOVERNOR, JULY, 1770; •PROCEEDS AGAINST PREDECESSOR AND OTHERS; •ROUSES OPPOSITION OF REGULARS; REFORMS ARMY AND ENGAGES IN OTHER PUBLIC WORKS;

94. SIMON DE ANDA Y SALAZAR •TROUBLES WITH MOROS CONTINUE; •RULE CHARACTERIZED BY HIS ENERGY, FORESIGHT, HONESTY, AND CONFLICTS WITH THE REGULARS; •DEATH, OCTOBER 30, 1776, AT 76 OF AGE; •TERM AS GOVERNOR, JULY, 1770-OCTOBER 30, 1776.

96. THE SUPREMACY OF THE FRIARS OVER THE COLONIAL GOVERNMENT

97. •THE DIFFERENT RELIGIOUS ORDERS HAD THE GREAT CONTRIBUTION IN THE ESTABLISHMENT OF SPANISH COLONIAL GOVERNMENT. •FRAILOCRACIA – MONASTIC SUPREMACY OF FRIARS WHO RULE THE PEOPLE. •THEY COULD INFLUENCE THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN EFFECT BECAME THE RULERS OF THE MUNICIPALITIES •THEY CONTROL THE DIFFERENT ASPECTS OF THE SOCIETY LIKE EDUCATION, TRADING, THE HACIENDAS, AND THE ECONOMY.

98. •SPANISH PRIEST – ARE THE REGULAR PRIEST •THESE PRIESTS DOMINATE AND CONTROL IN DIFFERENT PARISHES. •THEY HAVE THE POWER TO GET THE PARISHES FROM THE SECULAR PRIESTS. •FILIPINO PRIEST – ARE THE SECULAR PRIEST

99. ABUSES OF THE SPANISH GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS

100. •THE EXCESSIVE POWERS AND PRIVILEGES OF THE GOVERNOR GENERAL MADE HIM WEAK AND UNDISCIPLINED. •HIS PREROGATIVES OFTEN GAVE HIM THE OPPORTUNITIES TO REWARD HIS FAVORITES AND RELATIVES •HE PENALIZE THOSE WHO HAD DISPLEASED HIM. •HE OFTENTIMES LACKED THE MORAL STRENGTH TO RESIST CORRUPTION FOR MATERIAL ADVANCEMENT. •HE FILLED IN SOME POSITIONS IN THE GOVERNMENT FROM THE HIGHEST BIDDER THUS MANY OFFICIALS EXPLOITED THEIR OFFICES TO RECOVER THEIR EXPENSES AND TO ENRICH THEMSELVES.

101. •THE ALCALDE MAYOR WAS THE ADMINISTRATOR, JUDGE, AND MILITARY COMMANDER. •THE MOST CORRUPT BRANCH OF THE GOVERNMENT •HE CONTROLLED THE PROVINCIAL TRADE •HE BOUGHT THE PEOPLE’S RICE AND OTHER PRODUCTS AT LOW PRICES AND SOLD IT BACK TO THE NATIVES AT HIGH PRICES.

102. •HE COLLECTED ALL THE PRODUCTS TO COMPLETE HIS NEEDED QUOTA EVEN IN TIME OF POOR HARVEST OR CROPS FAILURE. •THUS LEAVING THE FARMERS WITH NO SEEDS FOR THE NEXT PLANTING •MORE TAXES WERE COLLECTED THAN REQUIRED BY LAW AND POCKETED THE EXCESS COLLECTIONS.

104. •IT BROUGHT ABOUT FREQUENT PERIODIC SHIFTS IN COLONIAL POLICIES AND PERIODIC RIGODON OF COLONIAL OFFICIALS. •THE PHILIPPINES WAS RULED BY 45 GOVERNOR GENERALS FROM 1849-1898 •EACH SERVING AN AVERAGE TERM OF ONLY ONE YEAR AND THREE MONTHS. •THERE WERE 4 GOVERNOR GENERALS FOR A PERIOD OF LESS THAN A YEAR FROM DECEMBER 1853 TO NOVEMBER 1854.

105. •THE FREQUENT CHANGE OF COLONIAL OFFICIALS HAMPERED THE POLITICAL AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT OF THE PHILIPPINES. •HARDLY HAD ONE GOVERNOR GENERAL BEGUN HIS ADMINISTRATION WHEN HE WAS SOON REPLACED BY HIS SUCCESSOR. •NATURALLY, NO CHIEF EXECUTIVE, NO MATTER HOW ABLE AND ENERGETIC HE WAS, COULD ACCOMPLISH MUCH FOR THE COLONY

107. •THE COLONIAL OFFICIALS SENT BY SPAIN TO THE PHILIPPINES IN THE 19TH CENTURY WERE A FAR CRY FROM THEIR ABLE AND DEDICATED PREDECESSORS OF THE 16TH 17TH AND 18TH CENTURIES. •THEY WERE HIGHLY CORRUPT, INCOMPETENT AND CRUEL. •THEY SYMBOLIZED THE DECADENT SPAIN OF THE 19TH CENTURY.

108. GENERAL RAFAEL DE IZQUIERDO (1871-1973), •A BOASTFUL, RUTHLESS GOVERNOR GENERAL, AROUSED THE ANGER OF THE FILIPINOS BY EXECUTING THE INNOCENT MARTYRS OF 1872.

109. ADMIRAL JOSE MALCAMPO (1874-1877) •SUCCESSOR OF IZQUIERDO, A GOOD MORO FIGHTER BUT WAS AN INEPT AND WEAK ADMINISTRATOR.

110. GENERAL FERNANDO PRIMO DE RIVERA •- GOVERNOR GENERAL FOR 2 TERMS (1880-1883, 1897- 1898) – ENRICHED HIMSELF BY ACCEPTING BRIBES FROM GAMBLING CASINOS IN MANILA WHICH HE SCANDALOUSLY PERMITTED TO OPERATE.

111. GENERAL VALERIANO WEYLER ( 1888-1891) • A CRUEL AND CORRUPT GOVERNOR GENERAL OF HISPANIC-GERMAN ANCESTRY, ARRIVED IN MANILA A POOR MAN AND RETURNED IN SPAIN A MILLIONAIRE.

112. GENERAL VALERIANO WEYLER ( 1888-1891) •HE RECEIVED HUGE BRIBES AND OF GIFTS OF DIAMONDS FOR HIS WIFE FROM WEALTHY CHINESE WHO EVADED THE ANTI- CHINESE LAW.

113. GENERAL VALERIANO WEYLER ( 1888-1891) •THE FILIPINOS SCOURNFULLY CALLED HIM “TYRANT” BECAUSE OF HIS CRUEL PERSECUTION OF THE CALAMBA TENANTS PARTICULARLY THE FAMILY OF RIZAL.

114. GENERAL VALERIANO WEYLER ( 1888-1891) • THE CUBANS CONTEMPTUOUSLY CURSED HIM AS “THE BUTCHER” BECAUSE OF HIS RUTHLESS RECONCENTRATION POLICY DURING HIS BRIEF GOVERNORSHIP IN CUBA IN 1896, CAUSING THE DEATH OF THOUSANDS OF CUBANS .

115. GENERAL CAMILO DE POLAVIEJA (1896-97) •AN ABLE MILITARIST BUT HEARTLESS GOVERNOR GENERAL , WAS WIDELY DETESTED BY FILIPINO PEOPLE FOR EXECUTING DR. JOSE RIZAL.

116. ACTIVITY 2

117. PHILIPPINE REPRESENTATION IN THE SPANISH CORTES

118. •FIRST PERIOD •THE PHILIPPINE REPRESENTATION IN THE SPANISH CORTES WAS FRUITFUL AND BENEFICAIL TO THE COLONY •SECOND AND THIRD PERIOD •IT WAS NOT FRUITFUL IN THE PARLIAENTARY WORKS •1837 – SPANISH CORTES WAS ABOLISHED •THE PHILIPPINE CONDITION WAS WORSEN

119. •MANY FILIPINOS VALIANTLY PLEADED TO THE RESTORATION OF THE SPANISH CORTES BUT IGNORED THE PLEA OF GRACIANO LOPEX JAENA AND HIS COMPATRIOTS. •THEIR GRIEVANCE WAS EMBITTERD BY THE FACT THAT CUBA AND PUERTO RICO WERE GRANTED REPRESENTATION IN THE SPANISH CORTES BY THE SPANISH CONSTITUTION OF 1876 •UNTIL THE END OF THE SPANISH RULE IN 1898, PHILIPPINE REPRESENTATION IN THE CORTES WAS NEVER RESTORED.

120. HUMAN RIGHTS DENIED TO FILIPINOS •SINCE THE ADOPTION OF THE SPANISH CONSTITUTION OF 1812 AND OTHER CONSTITUTIONS, THE PEOPLE OF SPAIN ENJOYED FREEDOM OF SPEECH, FREEDOM OF THE PRESS, FREEDOM OD ASSOCIATION, AND OTHER HUMAN RIGHTS •ALL OF THESE HUMANS RIGHTS AND CONSTITUTIONAL LIBERTIES WERE DENIED TO THE FILIPINOS IN ASIA.

121. NO EQUALITY BEFORE THE LAW •THE SPANISH MISSIONARIES WHO INTRODUCED CHRISTIANITY INTO THE PHILIPPINES IN 16TH CENTURY TAUGHT THAT: THAT ALL MEN , IRRESPECTIVE OF COLOR AND RACE ARE CHILDREN OF GOD THEY ARE BROTHERS AND EQUAL BEFORE GOD

122. NO EQUALITY BEFORE THE LAW •THE SPANISH ARROGANTLY REGARDED THE BROWN- SKINNED FILIPINOS AS INFERIOR BEINGS •THE FILIPINOS WERE NOT REGARDED AS THEIR CHRISTIAN BROTHERS TO BE PROTECTED BUT RATHER THEIR SUBJECT TO BE EXPLOITED.

123. NO EQUALITY BEFORE THE LAW •THE FILIPINOS WERE ABUSED, BRUTALIZED, PERSECUTED AND SLANDERED BY THEIR SPANISH MASTERS. •FILIPINOS COULD NOT APPEAL TO THE LAW FOR JUSTICE BECAUSE THE LAW IS ONLY FOR THE WHITE SPANIARDS.

125. THE SOCIAL STRATIFICATION/SOCIAL STRUCTURE THE SPANIARDS IMPOSED NEW SOCIAL STRATIFICATION WHCH DISCRIMINATE THE NATIVES IN THEIR OWN LAND. •PENINSULARES - IS CONSIDERED AS THE HIGHEST CLASS. THEY ARE THE SPANISH BORN IN SPAIN BUT LIVE IN THE PJHILIPPINES •INSULARES – THE SPANISH BORN IN THE PHILIPPINES AND CONSIDERED AS THE SECOND CLASS.

126. THE SOCIAL STRATIFICATION/SOCIAL STRUCTURE •THE CREOLES – THEY ARE THAT MIX BLOOD OR THE COMBINATION OF SPANISH AND FILIPINO OR THIRD CLASS. •ILLUSTRADO – THE WELL EDUCATED FILIPINO, THEY ARE UNDER CREOLES •PRINCIPALIA – LAND OWNERS ALSO UNDER CREOLES •INDIOS – OR THE NATIVES ARE CONSIDERED AS THE LAST CLASS

127. SPANIARDS PENINSULARES CREOLES INDIOS THEY ENJOYED LAWS AND SECURITY THEY ESTABLISHED THEIR COMMUNITY IN INTRAMUROS TO SEGREAGATE THEIR POPULATION FROM OTHER CLASS THEY ARE THE FIRST ONE WHO THOUGHT OF FIGHTING THE SPANIARDS TO SEEK REFORM THE UNFORTUNATE CLASS AND DISCRIMINATED FROM THE SOCIETY AND SUBJECTED TO NUMEROUS TAXATION

129. THE LITERATURE BECOMES THEOCENTRIC •FROM EPIC IT TURNS TO BE: •AWIT •CORRIDO •MORO-MORO •KOMEDYA •PASYON

130. •OUR ALIBATA WAS REPLACED BY ABECEDARIO OF THE SPANIARDS •THE FIRST BOOK PRINTED IN THE COUNTRY WAS THE DOCTRINA CHRISTIANA EN LETRA Y LEGUA CHINA. THE CENTERED IN THE SPREAD OF CATHOLICISM IN THE COUNTRY •PAINTINF WAS ALSO SECULARIZED BECAUSE OF THE SYNOD OF CALASIAO IN 1773 WHICH ORDERED THAT THE PAINTERS SHOULD USE THE CONCEPT OF THE CHURCH.
